clinical_study.official_title: The Intermountain Risk Score's Association With Mortality Prediction in Trauma Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators hypothesize that a risk score composed of age, sex, and the components of commonly ordered laboratory panels will be predictive of mortality in trauma patients, and will help improve clinicians' ability to make more accurate mortality predictions at the time of admission.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.description: To determine whether the Intermountain Risk Score accurately predicts 30 day mortality and one year mortality in trauma patients.
measure the ability of the Intermountain Risk Score to predict all cause mortality at one year after the traumatic event

secondary_outcome.description: compare the IMRS to experienced clinicians' ability to predict mortality at 30 days
compare the IMRS to experienced clinicians' ability to predict mortality at 1 year

study_pop.textblock: Individuals who suffer from a traumatic injury and present to the Emergency Department as a Trauma Activation

criteria.textblock:

- Patients who enter the hospital as "trauma consults." These patients have traumatic injuries, and are often admitted to the trauma service, but the severity of their trauma is not thought to warrant trauma team activation.
